text:
Carolina, people like you love to try and take the "oh I use logic and the left just have insults" line. Would you like to know why everyone is insulting you? Would you even be open to comprehending the motivation? 
How many conversations do you think we've had, in real life and in the cyber world, about our rights to exist? Conversation about how we want to be treated like everyone else (that is to say, love the ones we love, whether it looks like yours or not, marry who we want to, whether our choice in partner is what YOU and people like you would approve of), or to be able to exist without fear of an individual having real animosity towards us and doing something about it and being surrounded in those moments by people like *you*, who "don't hate us" but would be passive enough to keep us marginalized. 
How many? Have a guess?
The point is, your "science" is flawed, and we've heard it all before. Your "logic" is hopelessly idiotic, and we've heard it all before. Your "reason" isn't fully fleshed out at all, and obviously has way more to do with emotion (ironic that, but not unexpected) than anything even remotely reasonable, and we've HEARD it ALL before. 
But can we convince one such as you if any of that? 
Mostly, given history, nah. We can't. Cause you're ignorant, and people like you in the past have wanted nothing so much as to stay that way. 
Final note, a suggestion. If you'd like *not* to be insulted, try having options that aren't garbage. I hear it works wonders.

text: I grew up in a time when we were still allowed our childhood.  As a third grader (in US around 8 or 9 years) I didn't have my psyche dented by an onslaught of sex education, including homosexual "tolerance" training.  If you are gay, or believe you're gay, then in the world today you are free to live as you wish.  Must there always be the flamboyant fanfare... a demand that I judge you on your sexual preference before and above all else?  Most, no matter nationality, never try to proselytize to anyone heterosexuality, nor make it their complete "identity" as many gays do.  Therefore I believe the question might better be, "Are homosexual attitudes to heterosexuals improving?"

The Bible makes it clear that God designed sex to be engaged in only between a male and a female and only within the arrangement of marriage, just like Genesis 1:27,28 says. I donâ€™t hate homosexuals, but I canâ€™t approve of their conduct. I reject homosexual conduct, not people. Also, I can't approve "God loves everyone" under these circumstances! text:
You said "God loves the people who listen to him and have high moral standards". I encourage you to consider again.  That sentence sounds like the legalism of the Pharisees, for whom people were either "in" or "out". They were deeply misguided in this and corrected by Jesus. You surely know John 3:16 "For God so loved the WORLD". What is the world? It is everyone. Not just those who know and serve God. The verse does not say "God so loved the few who live in the right way."  If God's very nature is love, then by that very nature everyone is embraced by divine love. That means you, me, the vicar in the photo, the gay people marching or marrying, all the people posting here that say God does not exist. God loves even those who hate and reject God. Jesus tells us "love your enemies". A greatly respected and rarely practised teaching. Is God exempt from that advice? Studying the Bible and trying to live well are good things, but to be so, they simply flow out of love for God, knowing that:
Grace means there is nothing I can do that makes God love me more.
Grace means there is nothing I can do that makes God love me less.

Faith is not a word describing adherence to a moral code. "Now faith is confidence in what we hope for, and assurance about what we cannot see." Hebrews 11. 

May you "know as you are now known". 
Peace to you.

text:
As a proud & dedicated Straight Ally, I hope to attend Pride in London one year, as well as those of Blackpool, Brighton & Manchester.  Last week's Cumbria Pride in Carlisle was a resounding success and I composed the following poem, which I was honoured to perform on stage. I like to think that the words capture nicely the essence as to the need for Pride events.

WHY PRIDE?

To celebrate diversity, 
love and tolerance
To champion dignity, respect
and above all else, acceptance.

To educate against prejudice,
ignorance and bigotry.
To maintain the fight until these ills
are banished to history.

To reflect on battles won
in the name of LGBT rights.
To remember that more needs to be done.
in order to scale further heights.

So next time someone asks "Why Pride?"
Look them square in the eye.
Then reel off all those reasons
before saying with pride "THAT'S WHY".

So next time someone asks " Why Pride ? " Look them square in the eye . Then reel off all those reasons before saying with pride " THAT'S WHY " .

Homosexuality is just a phenomenon that scientists are still trying to explain, but that doesn't really affect the species in any way. Gay people are just people with different preferences or likes. Being gay doesn't have ANYTHING to do with being male or female. Get yourself together. Now, things happen genetically or behaviorally speaking... we are all changing everyday due to mutations, but the mutations that really have an impact on us are those that occurred before birth. Changes in the genes can lead us to be or act differently, that's probably why I'm gay, that's probably why some people are trans, that's probably why some people are taller than others, other people is born with different skin color, and others with syndromes that are harmful for them. LEARN how nature and life work so you can actually use them as arguments.

text:
Again, please use logic, rather than falling back on Bronze Age fairytales. 

Murder and theft differ from homosexuality in many ways. The first and most obvious is that the former two have victims (and hurt others), while homosexuality does not (outside of STDs, which can and are also transmitted by heterosexuals). The second is that murder and theft are choices, whereas homosexuality is not. 

I'd like to make what should be an obvious assertion for the third difference: theft and murder are crimes, and homosexuality is not. Tragically, however, several countries are as caught up in their hateful religious dogma as you are, and so I'm unable to conclusively make that point. Instead, I'll posit that, in all civilised societies, theft and murder and crimes, whereas homosexuality is not. 

Even supposing that, of the thousands of religions, yours was somehow "the right one" (it clearly isn't), any God that casts people into hell for eternity for refusing to believe while simultaneously providing laughably limited evidence for their existence is not a god worth praising. I believe that we make our own salvation in life in our quest to find enlightenment and live as good people.

text: Jesse, conveniently,  you left out Jesus Christ and His teachings, like most.  Just because there are people who do bad things in the name of Christianity because they are misguided or part of a cult that is falsely called Christianity,  does not mean every single one is like that.  You're generalizing and using extreme examples instead of recognizing the good people who follow the teachings of Jesus Christ.  When groups of atheists protest, riot and destroy property, I do not say all atheists are violent,  despicable people as a whole.    The OP left Jesus Christ out of his posts as well.  I addressed this before.   He's incorrect by doing so.  He's just name calling and insulting people because it's the only way he can feel superior in his world.   It's easy to point fingers at others while failing to pluck the log out of your own eye.   Many struggle with this,  including myself.  However,   leaving out Jesus Christ and His teachings is not really speaking about Christianity.

text:
"remember Sodom and Gomorrah, History wasnt ment to be repeated you know"
Why do people never read the Bible? Sodom was an anti rape story and Gomorrah was a passing mention. And you think this is history? LMAO

Claims he has "nothing but love towards all people"
Calls homosexuality "disgusting"

"irregardless of their lifestyle choices however disgusting they may be"
So you shouldn't have any problem with homosexuality then, seeing as it's not a lifestyle choice.

"but the truth still needs to be said, someone needs to speak out against this new found freedom to sin, have you no shame?"
The truth needs to be shown to be true. Demonstrate it is, objectively, a sin and we will listen.

Says "i urge you to read the Holy Bible and learn the truth"
Doesn't understand Sodom was an anti rape story

"am sorry you need to go back and read the Bible, or anything that improves thought"
"The Bible" and "something that improves thought" shouldn't be in the same sentence.

"Homosexuality is wrong"
That which can be asserted without evidence may be dismissed without evidence.

"Lennart Roos, the same way murders, thieves, peverts, R Kelly affects me, they are infringing on my freedom to practice my faith and to a peaceful life"
If people you don't even know affect you that much, you may want to reprioritize.

"i mean realy, how am i supposed to live a peaceful life when i hear gay this and gay that everytime i turn on the news, gays should hide their gayness, HIDE IT, aint no1 wanna know, Stay in the closet and STOP fighting for rights that heterosexual people enjoy, yall not on the same level"
What was that you said above? You "have nothing but love towards all people". I find it hard to believe.

text: Paul, you cannot prove God does not exist.  Just like we cannot prove there is no life outside of our solar system.   That doesn't make it an unwarranted theory until it is proven wrong.  Steven Hawkins believes there are other beings in the universe.   Does that make him delusional and ignorant?  Obviously not.   You have a choice to believe or not to.  Many people believe in some sort of higher power.  Just because we cannot touch it or see it doesn't make it any less true or plausible.   It's a great mystery that will be revealed.   Personally, I know there is something greater than me because I feel His presence.  You cannot prove my experiences wrong either.   You cannot prove Steven Hawkins is wrong.

text:
Well, there's quite a lot to answer there! I'll ignore the global warming red herring at the end (nice try, though, petal).

1. Genetically, there are 2 SEXES, not genders. "Sex" refers to biological differences (hormones, genitalia etc), whereas gender refers to sociocultural norms associated with sex. (See WHO's website for details; see also Pavlov 2014). Conflating sex and gender really is a schoolboy error (or is that expression not considered PC enough?)

2. The science isn't settled that being transgender is a mental disease. You're either deliberately misinterpreting the facts or have misunderstood them.

3. Johns Hopkins has recently reopened its gender clinic, and now performs gender reassignment treatments after re-evaluating McHugh's findings. 

4. Citing McHugh alone ignores the scores of other psychiatrists whose findings differ greatly from those presented by McHugh (for example Colizzi et al, De Cuypere et al., and so on).

5. The methodology in Hopkins research was criticised for being flawed almost immediately after its publication. It judged patients to be "poorly adjusted" if they were involved in relationships with someone of the same sex post-transition. 

6. Thepublicdiscourse is run by a far-right think-tank, and can thus be discredited due to ideological interference. Present a more neutral source and you might have an argument.

7. McHugh's findings can also be discredited based on ideological conflict; in 1992, he admitted that his goal was to have the gender clinic at Johns Hopkins shut down after taking it over in 1975, 4 years before his "findings" were made public. Isn't that a swell coincidence? (See McHugh, 1992).

8. Gender dysphoria (arguably an offshoot of ego-dystonic sexual identity disorder) certainly exists, but not everyone who is trans suffers from it. 

9. You don't "enable" a mental disorder. They occur. Reassignment therapy can be seen as a form of treatment for those who suffer from gender dysphoria.

10. I actually agree that children should not undergo reassignment therapy, for the simple reason that their development has not finished, and thus it's possible that they may change as they advance through their teenage years. 

11. Hopkins is but one hospital. Their policy is not representative of other hospitals where reassignment therapy has proven
 to be a success over a prolonged period. 

12. You cite McHugh yet do not provide the name or coauthors of his work, nor do you explain the methodology. You're simply regurgitating the information that you found on a far right website. 

13. Johns Hopkins were quick to distance themselves from McHugh, contending that his research doesn't represent their views.

I'm sure that your life would be more fulfilling if you didn't waste it trying to make others miserable, babe. Oh, and "liberal" isn't really an insult, given that it means "free", although it speaks volumes about your own ideology and outlook. You take care now xoxoxo

text: Let me educate you about this so called "front line" in battle.  ALL British Army troops, are trained to fire a weapon per se. This is because in wars,battles etc the "front line" is where a soldier engages the enemy. Now wars are not fought like they were a hundred + years ago, where they all face each other across no mans land and then attack each other. The front line can be anywhere the enemy engages you. For example In the Iraq war many USA supply vehicles were ambushed, and  the male and female drivers/cooks/Ordnance troops on the vehicles,were suddenly engaging the enemy in a contact. So basically any and ALL troops are trained to a battle standard fighting grade..

text:
As a former solder. I have a few questions. Do transgender recruits get their own rooms separate from male & females or do the men have to share with someone born a female or women share with someone born a man?

Do transgender also benefit from the different minimum requirements for men & women to be a soldier? As its easier for a woman to be a solder & pass all tests than it is a man, because women get longer to run the 3 1/2 mile run & so forth. So does a man now a woman, fall under female rules or keep the male rules? 

Finally, If I was sharing barracks or whatever with a transgender female that was born a man. Who will most likely be attracted to men. I would feel uncomfortable being around such a person & be offended if such interest was gazed upon myself.

Lydia Grace Epner You're right. But if by sex your a man, how can you then be classified by gender as a women? You're still a man & should be classified as a man. I have nothing against how people live their lives as long as it doesn't have any negative impact on anyone else's. No one has any right to live a life at the detriment of others. But we're now being forced to share changing rooms, toilets with someone of a different sex to us. 

Put it this way, a mother can be naked in the same room as their teenage daughter, for example in changing rooms or when trying on clothing. A father can be the same with his son. However, a father cannot with the daughter or mother with the son. Because it's indecent. So re classifying gender doesn't mean you now can. So if the law states your of the opposite sex, that makes you a man.

text:
So, to take your points in turn:

1) There was a study performed by RAND Corp. in 2016 to determine the effects of having transgender people in the military, and the cost was determined to be negligible.  So, ultimately, "cutting corners" is not really all that necessary in this situation.

2) That study also examined several other military forces around the world that have transgender people enlisted and found no significant instances of loss of unit cohesion or morale.

3) That same study again noted that the number of transgender people serving between 1320 and 6630.  It's tough to get an accurate number because it's not something the DoD really tracks, but some estimates put it above 10,000.  That's not proven, though.

At any rate, I think the important thing is that for people serving in the military, beyond gender, beyond race, beyond background, beyond sexuality, you are first a soldier.  It's one of the first things you learn there.  As long as leadership is in place, then any gender, sexuality, or gender identity can serve alongside each other.  

No, it's not going to be perfect, and yes, there will probably be incidents, but I applaud these folks for their voluntary service.  I certainly didn't have the fortitude.

Here's the study, if you're interested:

text: Scott Zdankiewicz These comments underlie the long term feud between leftists and people with right-wing views over opinion whether transsexualism is a mental disorder or not. This is a similar dicussion like the issue of abortion where some consider it murder while others a medical treatment. I think this is an insoluble problem which always triggering fierce dispute. Although I don't consider transgenders less capable of fighting and having weaker fortitude than others, I think that enlisting them to army would entail more mundane problems like bathrooms, toilets and so on but if any army wanted to accept them, it would tackle this small problem for sure. The problem is whether people with "mental disorder" should be conscripted into army or not. A man without legs wouldn't be accepted by army (although I am not sure) but it is visible disorder while transgenderism is a disputable subject.

text: Tim Smith, it's not immediately clear from your profile where in the world you are but, in case you are American, I think it is worth pointing out that, in the last 50 years 10.5k people have been killed as a result of terrorism across the whole of Western Europe. Or, indeed, those who have been murdered by other means. And, don't even get me started on the unholy mess the orange spangletwat and his cohorts are trying to make of your healthcare system. So...who is letting down who's citizens again?

text:
Its weird how 18 countries allow transgender people in thier armies, yet the world still turns to America in times of trouble...

The suicide rate among Transgendered individuals is roughly 37%.  That means that statistically, 1/3rd of those with Gender dysphoria are already disqualified from service.  Then you have to worry about which PT test they take, and what jobs they can and cant hold because of their sex.  Then you have to worry about battle stress and PTSD affecting those who are already dealing with GD.  No one is calling them less of a human.  No one is "taking away their rights" the military is not about making exceptions, rather, building a force that can think and act as one cohesive unit, without questioning whether their battle buddy is up to saving their life at any time.  Thats why there are a whole litney of both physical and mental disorders that disqualify someone from service.

text:
Ah, but there's a difference between doing "what's best", and doing something for political points.  

Did you know that this all started with the US House of Representatives arguing about whether Dept. of Defense funds should be used for gender reassignment surgery for transgender soldiers?  Because it might have led to a bill failing, something Trump didn't want to keep happening, House Republicans turned to him to address the idea of such funding.

So he said he was banning transgender people entirely.  Not just the surgery.  Not just those looking to seek surgery.  The entire transgender population of the US military, which number in the thousands.

Now I agree there's a hardy debate to be had about whether or not to use funds for such surgery, but the idea of using that as an opportunity to completely ban a group of people from serving is throwing the baby out with the bathwater.

There are transgender people right now serving in the US military not seeking surgery, nor taking regular hormone treatments.  There are also people who have completed transitioning that don't need regular treatments.

So these are able people that are being denied their privilege to serve their country, when it has been proven via a study performed by RAND Corp in 2016 that not only is the monetary burden negligible, but also proved through referencing other countries that openly have transgender people serving (like the UK) that there is no effect on morale or unit cohesion.

I agree there are times to be doing things for the best even if some people don't like it (such as marriage equality being passed in the US two years ago), but you have to still do the work and learn whether it really is for the best, or if it's only to look good for certain people.

text:
some people mix up God's dislike of certain behaviors with the people themselves, so they may say that God hates homosexuals. These people are of the belief that homosexuality is a sin in God's eyes and that a marriage union is only acceptable if it is between a man and a woman.

Yet, we are all sinners, Christian and non-Christian teens alike, and God loves us all. Every single person, homosexual or not, is special in God's eyes. Sometimes it is about our own views of our behaviors that lead us to believe we are less special in God's eyes. If you are of a denomination that has deemed homosexuality as a sin, you may be faced with guilt about your same-sex attraction. However, it is your own guilt that makes you think that God loves you less.

text: So this is how liberty dies . . . With thunderous applause. Ladies and gentlemen, the Supreme Court just reneged on its constitutional duty to uphold the law of the land. The Supreme Court has indeed violated the constitutional principle of separation of powers and the Tenth Amendment, which specifically states that any authority not given to the federal government via our Constitution is a power that belongs to the states. As of today, religious liberty in America has been weakened to satisfy the Machiavellian demands of a vociferous few. The brainwashed populace now lauds this ruling in defiance of God's law and in violation of the Constitution of the United States. America has blindly acquiesced to the demands of the LGBT community in ignorance of the truth that their agenda poses an existential threat to the American Republic. Fellow Christians, it is time to stand up in defiance of this ruling and openly proclaim the truth regardless of the consequences. "And you shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free." (John 8:32, NKJV). God help our United States of America!

text:
Society intends to push various lies:

1) Everyone that doesn't agree with your choices is "hateful", "fearful"(phobic), or "bigot", which is their favorite invented word.

2) To love, respect or feel empathy one have to accept everyone's choices. 

3) That there's no compassion without acceptance. 

They're wrong, and they know it. 

No one needs to accept something wrong to be compassionate. No one has to renounce to their own criteria to comply with other people's decisions. 
I don't need violence or lies to express my point. And certainly, don't need to victimize myself to tell the truth.

text: The people of Lot lived in a society very similar to our own. It was corrupt, the people had no shame, criminals and criminal activity abounded, and those passing through the town of Sodom risked robbery and physical abuse. The overall atmosphere of the town was not one of a cohesive society.  The people of Lot were without morals, without standards and without shame. The homosexuality that abounded did not exist in a vacuum, it was part of a lifestyle that not only allowed, but also encouraged vice and corruption. It was to this town that God sent Prophet Lot; his message was to worship God alone. However, embedded in worship are the desire and the willingness to obey Godâ€™s commandments? The people of Sodom were content with their corrupt ways and had no desire to curb them. Lot became an annoyance and his words were ignored.

text: Today is not a day to hate and it's assuredly not a day to rejoice over new "freedoms." Today is a day that I mourn. I mourn over a nation that calls good evil and evil good. I mourn over our nation that the world looks to that now, once again, takes the lead in leading the world astray. I mourn for those who say, "This doesn't affect you so why do you care?" because this does effect me, as I live in a nation coming under increased judgment, and because this does effect me, as my heart aches watching people drink sand in the desert believing it will satisfy. I mourn that God puts blessing and cursing before us, telling us to choose, and we time and again choose curses. I mourn over humanity who continues reaching to find satisfaction outside of Jesus but will never find it because there is no soul-deep satisfaction apart from the One who created us. "There are many people outside the court today who are exuberant because they believe that what the court has done today will fulfill them and make them happy. Just like the woman at the well, who Jesus encountered, it won't do that." I mourn for the true meaning of marriage being lost in all this, Christ loving the church and the church submitting to Jesus. I mourn for pastors and church leaders who, even though many still naively laugh at the idea, will soon face compromise or prison on this issue. I mourn for many followers of Christ who are tossed to and fro by every wind of doctrine because of a lack of knowledge of God's Word and God's Will. I mourn for all those who boldly say "Jesus loved all" but don't understand that Jesus' love also called them to leave their life of sin and died a brutal death for our rebellion. And I mourn for the American church that either sits silently while the world collapses or screams hate from the sidelines. Yet today I am reminded that the Supreme Court can't put Jesus back in the tomb. Jesus is alive. He's still ruling and reigning. And He's coming back. How I ache and long for that day. But until that day comes I will continue to speak Truth, proclaim the Way, and show true Life. Jesus is the only answer for all our brokenness. Today I feel it more than most others - the Spirit and your true BRIDE say, "COME LORD JESUS!" AMERICA HAS FALLING

text: Jane and Lee. There's a couple of things. 1. People's sexual habits are quite a small part of their sexuality. There is a history, a culture, a vocabulary all born from oppression which is part of our individual and collective identity as an LGBT community. When you reduce someones identity to sex you objectify them and begin to dehumanise them. It's a common mistake and one that many LGBT people make as well, but try to think of this articles in terms of people's experience rather than their sex lives. 2. There is a common oppressive discourse that gay people (men specifically) are peadophiles. I know you're not suggesting this in your reference to peadophilia but even using the term in the same sentence implies a connection. That is oppressive, if you don't want to offend LGBT people stop referring to peadophiles in any context wen talking about LGBT people. 3. Straight people don't need to come out, everyone presumes your straight, be thankful for this. Coming out is scary and sometimes has a negative result for the person doing the coming out. 4. Getting on with our lives and living and let living is not about ignoring difference, it's about celebrating diversity. So pretending homophobia doesn't exist and 'we are all in it together' is difficult for people that have experienced oppression. Ya'll have a good day now xx

text:
Very good idea, but I think that LGBT people should feel safe wherever they are, why should they have to have places like this.  The laws should be robust enough to deal with anyone making life difficult.

As a woman with Asperger Syndrome I would love to have a place though where it is disabled women only and I wouldn't get hassle or sexual advances from men.  Even though I am hetero, I am not interested in a relationship but have had so many problems with men who live in neighbouring flats.  This is very difficult so I would like women only, but why should I have to live apart from the males of society because some want to be difficult.  The issue of sexual harassment, especially of disabled women is another thing that should not have to happen.

text: It sounds like discrimination to me, like creating a ghetto to isolate people that other people don't want to get involved with. In other countries they used to create hospitals to black people (as if there were any kind of black people), hospitals to white people (as if there were any kind of white people), schools to black children, schools to white children, remember? Is this option any less wrong? Remember: couples are just that: couples. And old folks are just that: old folks, who deserve to be loved and respected. One day, any one of us will be, if we're lucky to get there. Respect them. Being segregated in a home is bad enough. Shame.

text: I don't see the problem in the idea. Speaking as lecurer of 16-19 year olds in the subject of health and social care, there is a radical difference between their generation and mine with regards to acceptance (and not just tolerance) of non-hetrosexual cisgender people and issues. I bring it up constantly in my teaching and have a significant number of case study issues that bring up sexuality and gender in younger and older case studies. They are, most of the time, very "okay" with it and get quite affronted with inequality. I am of the view that in the future, such an instituation will start to become null void as a "requirement"  - the future generation will embrace this. But I'm being hopeful.

text:
^^^ what Karyn said. Basically Jane, you totally understand that you would prefer to spend time in an environment where people don't discriminate against you - and so would I. What your first comment failed to understand is that being LGBT is not just about sex, it's about who we love and how we have lived our lives. I don't want myself or anyone else to have to go back into the closet because of fear on old age. Yes, in time attitudes will, are and have changed BUT even if all was perfect I have lived my life surrounded by my LGBT community and I would like to continue to have the chance to do so. We have a shared life experience as a community that will probably be even more valuable to me as I grow older. We make decisions about who we live with when we are adults, why should we have this taken away and treated like children when we are older?
I also think many will take issue with you on "sexuality going down the pan" when you are old - is that your lived experience or are you projecting your feeling for a cause?

text: Yes, you can have special homes built for the LBG community. I want homes for people who are interesting and intelligent, don't swear. We can have other homes for Black people, Asian people, disabled people. Lots and lots of homes just tailor made for me and me not forgetting me. We are all human beings whatever our sexual orientation. I suppose it will take many years for the LBG community to have the confidence to accept themselves and not feel the need to keep reminding us of their sexual preferences and orientation. Those who don't accept the LBG community will find it lonely in their old age because they will be in the minority. I'm 73 and hope I never end up in a home. The thought isn't a pleasant one for me and when we are well and fit isn't for anybody. If I do have to then I hope I will be able to enjoy good conversation and laughter with whoever is sitting next to me whatever their sexual orientation and still have the compassion to listen.

text:
Is your bathroom at home split into male/female? When you go to an event or festival do you all use the same ports-potty? It's not about comfort or safety - just discrimination and misunderstanding.

text: I see your point and understand it. Your right in a lot of ways. However, actively calling trans people fucking weird and using words like "shemale" contribute to the idea that trans people are not normal or therefore worthy of being treated equally.
